Mice could hold the key to stem-cell research.

Hi, Madeleine.
First, Joe, tell us about this new research.
Scientists were actually able to turn skin cells into stem cells?
That's right.

And you remember, embryonic stem cells are those cells that can turn into any cell in the body.

And so after experimenting with a bunch of different genes, some scientists in Japan found four that seemed to do the trick, that seemed to transform an adult cell into a cell that behaved a lot more like an embryonic stem cell.

And now there's a series of papers coming out today that had replicated that and shown that, yes, indeed these stem cells are, even though they came from skin cells, they're indistinguishable from embryonic stem cells that were derived from embryos.
So the idea being that any old cell on any part of your body could become a stem cell.
Right.
That's the cool thing because right now the way they get embryonic stem cells is they take them from an early developing embryo.
